channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Now Tory MPs demand the head of Dominic Cummings: Top Brexiteer Steve Baker leads backbench anger
item.description: Steve Baker, a former Brexit minister and a senior hardline Brexiteer like Mr Cummings, broke cover to demand the advisor be removed, demanding the Prime Minister 'take back control'.

item.title: Wuhan Virology institute director refutes Covid-19 claims
item.description: The Wuhan Institute of Virology director Wang Yanyi has said that while the facility has three strains of the viruses, their highest similarity to Covid-19 only reached 79.8 per cent.

item.title: Thousands of Hong Kong protesters are tear-gassed by police
item.description: Riot police have clashed with pro-democracy protesters demonstrating against a bill that will ban secessionist and subversive activity in Hong Kong.

item.title: Boris Johnson is set to ease restrictions for outdoor activities
item.description: The Prime Minister is keen to welcome back a selection of open-air businesses and events, with a return for National Trust parks also on the agenda, providing indoor attractions remain shut.

item.title: Premier League footballer is accused of 'gang rape' at lockdown party
item.description: The woman in question says she woke up at a flat in the UK next to an unnamed footballer then received a phone call from an anonymous person telling her that she'd been spiked.

item.title: BBC is 'preparing' to scrap free TV licences for over-75s in August, says Lord Hall
item.description: The BBC is 'preparing' to scrap free TV licences for over-75s in August, says Lord Hall.

item.title: Coronavirus infections rocketed from 200,000 to 1.5million in the days before lockdown
item.description: A study by Professor Neil Ferguson's Imperial College unit estimates the real number of coronavirus cases in the UK was doubling every three days at the start of Britain's battle.

item.title: Oxford University vaccine trial has only a 50% chance of success because virus is vanishing in UK
item.description: Professor Adrian Hill said the upcoming trial of 10,000 Britons may produce 'no result' because the virus is vanishing. Scientists have discussed purposely infecting volunteers.

item.title: 'Secret millionaire' who buys fish-and-chip suppers for village offers £100 to locals to lose weight
item.description: An anonymous benefactor who has paid for weekly meals from The Fox pub in Denchworth, Oxfordshire, is now offering villagers a £100 incentive to lose 10 per cent of their body weight in two months.

item.title: County Durham two-bed home costs £175 monthly rent but locals warn 'you get what you pay for'
item.description: The two-bedroom end-terrace home has been listed for rent in the former mining village of Horden on Fifth Street. Experts believe it is the cheapest family home to rent in the UK for many years.

item.title: Muslims around the world celebrate Eid under lockdown restrictions
item.description: Three-day holiday is traditionally a time for travelling, family celebrations and lavish daytime feasts However, this year it will be a much quieter celebration.

item.title: EastEnders actress Heather Chasen dies aged 92
item.description: Heather's friend, Amanda Barrie, 84, tweeted about her ex's death this morning. Heather was Lydia Simmonds in the BBC show EastEnders, Janine Butcher's grandmother.

item.title: Tories rebel as Trade Secretary Liz Truss 'plots to betray UK farmers' for Trump deal
item.description: Liz Truss (pictured) has clashed with George Eustice, who fears that Ms Truss is preparing to ditch the UK's animal welfare and environmental standards.

item.title: The Queen rides her favourite black pony at Windsor Castle
item.description: Most mornings, a stooped but sprightly lady in a headscarf, jodhpurs and riding boots slips out of a side door at Windsor Castle in Berkshire.

item.title: Steve Coogan faces further fury as it emerges his TV production company furloughed NINE staff
item.description: Seven full-time employees and two temporary staff at Baby Cow Productions are reportedly being paid by the Government's coronavirus support scheme, which is funded by the taxpayer.

item.title: Jacqueline Jossa 'SPLITS from husband Dan Osborne after three years of marriage'
item.description: It is claimed that their marriage became 'unworkable' while in lockdown and the former TOWIE star, 28, is believed to have left their family home.

item.title: Model claims Usain Bolt begged her for photos just days before his long-term girlfriend gave birth
item.description: Despite claiming to have had several conversations, the glamour girl insists Bolt never mentioned partner, Kasi Bennett and that she only found out about the birth when it was tweeted by the Jamaican premier.

item.title: 'I wish I'd been kinder at the end': Joe Wicks reveals guilt over split from Swedish ex-girlfriend
item.description: He has reportedly been put forward for an OBE for his efforts in raising money for the NHS from his lockdown workouts. But Joe Wicks has admitted that he hasn't always put kindness first.

item.title: Entrepreneur behind miracle serum says sales are up by 250 per cent during the covid-19 lockdown
item.description: Eli Cohen, 29, from Leeds, is the man behind the serum from Amazon best-seller SKINKISSED. He said the brand was selling one product every 30 seconds since the start of the covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: The colours you MUST wear to boost your mood
item.description: Susie Hasler, who runs Styled By Susie, has shared how to introduce colour to your outfit, which colours evoke certain moods and which to wear for each lockdown occasion,

item.title: Prince Harry made decision to quit Royal Family NOT Meghan Markle
item.description: A publishing source told The Sun that while Meghan was supportive of Harry's choice to leave, she 'asked him if he was certain it was what he wanted' multiple times.

item.title: Soap opera fans will be forced to kiss goodbye to lip-locking sessions in their favourite shows
item.description: EastEnders and Emmerdale have employed a 'no snogs' policy and characters will be banned from kissing because of social distancing guidelines put in place by the Government.

item.title: Lockdown was a waste of time and could kill more than it saved, claims Nobel laureate
item.description: Michael Levitt, a Stanford University professor who correctly predicted the scale of the pandemic, suggested the decision to keep people indoors was motivated by 'panic' rather than the best science.

item.title: New photos reveal damage from San Francisco warehouse fire
item.description: Pictures taken after the blaze was extinguished show the structure destroyed by the fire, with its walls and roof collapsed.

item.title: Princess Charlotte may stay at home when her classes restart next month
item.description: Princess Charlotte, five, is in reception at Thomas's school in Battersea, London, while George is in year 2. Under government guidelines reception, year 1 and year 6 classes are to reopen from June 1.

item.title: DAN HODGES: Liberal 'morality' only puts migrants' lives in even MORE danger
item.description: DAN HODGES: How can we have allowed this to happen again? Why has Farage been allowed to run rings around the political establishment and hijack the immigration agenda?

item.title: How to make classic cheese and bacon rolls in a slow cooker
item.description: A woman has shared how to cook delicious cheese and bacon pull apart rolls in a slow cooker instead of the oven. The recipe itself it easy to follow and takes two hours to cook high.

item.title: First of five Iranian tanker crosses into Venezuela's economic zone
item.description: The oil tanker Fortune was welcomed by Venezuelan officials who celebrated the growing relationship with Iran spurred by disdain for the U.S.

item.title: Boris on brink of Huawei climbdown as spy chiefs reveal new fears
item.description: Boris Jonson's (pictured) climbdown comes after a growing rebellion on the Tory backbenches, with Downing Street privately conceding they cannot get the plan through the Commons.

item.title: DR ELLIE CANNON answers 50 questions we all want to ask a GP
item.description: DR ELLIE CANNON: Numbers contacting GPs are down across the UK. With this in mind, I'll bring the GP to you with my vital guide to coping with all of your family's health problems at home.

item.title: Pizza Express could permanently close scores of its 470 UK restaurants
item.description: The Mail on Sunday understands Pizza Express could go through a restructuring process known as a CVA.

item.title: Fortnum and Mason's prestigious Drink and Food Awards go digital, co-hosted by Claudia Winkleman
item.description: Cookbooks by big name chefs like Gordon Ramsay, Nigella Lawson and Nigel Slater lost out to niche texts in the UK-based Fortnum & Mason Food and Drink Awards.

item.title: Artist reveals how eating a brownie laced with angel dust led her to experience nervous breakdowns
item.description: Ruth Poniarsky, 64, from New York, revealed how taking the anaesthetic PCP at university led to a series of nervous breakdowns throughout her life.

item.title: As Covid-19 runs riot in Russia, Putin has lost his aura of invincibility says MICHAEL BURLEIGH
item.description: This year was to have been the pinnacle of Vladimir Putin's political career, when the 75th anniversary of Russia's victory in the Great Patriotic War coincided with his 20 years of rule.

item.title: Trump says Biden's 'doesn't remember what he did yesterday'
item.description: In a brief clip for Sunday's 'Full Measure with Sharyl Attkisson', Trump quickly lambasted Biden as being forgetful.

item.title: Young people are joining the rich in leaving NYC for cheaper, less dense cities after coronavirus
item.description: The majority of New Yorkers who fled the city intend to return, but the economic impact of the pandemic as well as the shift to remote working has led others to ditch the city for good.

item.title: 'Organisation queen', 25, reveals how she stores her food so it lasts longer
item.description: An Australian 'organisational queen' has revealed her best tips for keeping your fridge clean and tidy after every grocery shop - and the DIY deodoriser she puts in the appliance to keep it fresh.

item.title: Police identify body found in woods as belonging to Louise Smith, 16
item.description: Forensic offers were today searching properties in Havant, Hampshire after a body was found in nearby woodland as they searched for 16-year-old Louise Smith, who vanished on May 8.

item.title: Coronavirus could be completely wiped out in Britain by September 30
item.description: A team at the Singapore University of Technology plotted data from the pandemic to pinpoint the date cases will die out. The UK's pandemic could be over by September 30.

item.title: Victoria Beckham launches skincare range while her husband David is said to be using hair thickener
item.description: Former Spice Girl Victoria is launching a new skincare range that includes a £180 a bottle face serum. Her husband David has reportedly started using hair thickening spray.

item.title: Are you self-isolating... with a ghost?
item.description: You may be weary of seeing the same four walls every day, but spare a thought for those stuck at home with a paranormal presence

item.title: Police 'interview man in connection with attack on England and Arsenal great Kenny Sansom'
item.description: The 61-year-old is thought to have fallen and suffered a serious head injury during the disagreement and was taken to hospital. Sansom was unable to recall the incident.

item.title: 'I didn't even know men could get breast cancer'
item.description: For 30 years doctors dismissed Richard Mead's worries about a lump in his chest - and when at last he was taken seriously, it was too late

item.title: Ministers vow to build 3,300 homes over a year to 'end rough sleeping for good' in £160m drive
item.description: The 3,300 houses are due to be made available in the next 12 months. Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick (pictured) said the cash injection as 'unprecedented'.

item.title: Kim Jong Un appears in public for first time in more than three weeks as he hosts a military meeting
item.description: Kim Jong-Un made his first public appearances in three weeks by holding a meeting to discuss how North Korea can improve its nuclear capabilities.

item.title: Why escape Brussels to kowtow to Beijing, asks former Australian prime minister TONY ABBOTT
item.description: TONY ABBOTT: It's not that this virus has changed the nature of the Chinese regime; but it has made its repressive, secretive and self-aggrandising side glaringly obvious.
item.media:credit: Visual China Group via Getty Ima

item.title: Wuhan virus lab was signed off by Michel Barnier in 2004 - despite French intelligence warnings
item.description: The construction of the Chinese laboratory at the centre of mounting suspicion over the source of the Covid-19 pandemic was signed off by Michel Barnier - despite warnings by French intelligence.

item.title: Woman with Down's Syndrome launches legal bid to end abortion 'discrimination'
item.description: Heidi Crowter, 24, who has Down's Syndrome, is launching a legal bid to change the country's abortion law, which she says is 'downright discriminatory.

item.title: TALK OF THE TOWN: Prince Harry's former wingman is set to fly to LA to heal rift
item.description: TALK OF THE TOWN: Tom 'Skippy' Inskip, who lives in Washington DC, is making plans to take his company's private jet to LA with his newborn son Albert to meet Prince Harry and Archie.

item.title: 'Quintessential' lupin seeds are packed with protein... but watch out if you have a peanut allergy
item.description: They are a quintessential feature of any English country garden. But lupins are fast becoming the latest culinary trend - because they are packed with important protein.

item.title: WHO hails 'goodwill ambassador' Peng Liyuan but fails to mention she's wife of China's President
item.description: Peng Liyuan is listed on WHO's website alongside former Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson Becker as one of nine 'goodwill ambassadors'.

item.title: Writer in her 30s says her 5ft frame and youthful looks make people think she's 12
item.description: Melanie Bell, a Canadian author who lives in the United Kingdom, recalls being carded at bars and being asked if she's old enough to go through airport security.

item.title: Hardline councils that refuse to reopen primary schools risk causing 'lifelong damage' warn experts
item.description: Hardline councils that refuse to reopen their primary schools next week risk causing 'lifelong damage' to some of the country's most deprived children, experts warned last night.

item.title: Father of Aya Hachem, 19, tells of heartbreak as family returns to Lebanon for her funeral
item.description: Aya Hachem was walking to Lidl supermarket near her family home in Blackburn when she was shot. Her father Ismail Hachem - a former soldier - questioned how his family will feel safe again.

item.title: Gavin Williamson ditches plans to cut long summer school holidays due to 'fierce union opposition'
item.description: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has quietly ditched plans to end the 'out-dated' long summer school holidays in favour of summer camps in the face of fierce opposition from unions.

item.title: Future of Channel Four is under threat as it faces 'biblical' cash crisis
item.description: Channel 4 has just £10 million to spend by the end of 2020 after its budget was cut by £150 million, putting the channel's existence under serious threat.

item.title: New books reveals details of White Bulger's infamous 2011 capture after 16 years on the lam
item.description: An excerpt of a new book reveals how Whitey Bulger remained defiant even as feds armed with multiple automatic weapons closed in on the then 81-year-old in the garage of his apartment complex.

item.title: Do you know if your blood pressure is high? How to give yourself a full body MOT on your sofa
item.description: At present, routine screening and annual health check-ups are suspended. With this in mind, here are the essential health checks you can do right now, from home.

item.title: Left-wing trolls target BBC's Laura Kuenssberg again after she appeared to defend Dominic Cummings
item.description: BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg faced fierce criticism yesterday after appearing to defend Dominic Cummings following reports that he had flouted lockdown rules.

item.title: Charles Dickens was cruel to his wife, hated his mother and had an affair, writes A.N. WILSON
item.description: Was his demise brought on by a frenzy of passion with the woman who had been his muse for so long? Or was the story no more than scandalous Victorian tittle-tattle?
item.media:credit: The Print Collector via Getty Im

item.title: North Korean TV erases Kim Jong Un's emblem from various programmes after his official title change
item.description: North Korean TV removed the emblem from several features about Kim and a daily propaganda video after his title change from Supreme Commander to head of state and Commander-in-Chief.

item.title: Mosques across Britain could sound the call to prayer through loudspeakers
item.description: Communities were allowed to use public address systems to alert the faithful during the holy month of Ramadan. Pictured: Newham's Minhaj-ul-Quran hopes to make the call to prayer every day.

item.title: Ex-brother-in-law of PM's chief aide comes to his defence over allegations he broke lockdown rules
item.description: Number 10's version of events began to unravel last night when Durham Constabulary released a contradictory statement revealing it was contacted the political aide's father.

item.title: A mandatory 14-day quarantine for arrivals is bonkers, say DAVID DAVIS and DAVID BLUNKETT
item.description: Home Secretary Priti Patel's (pictured) policy is a devastating blow for anyone hoping to holiday abroad this summer, for the airline industry and for British international businesses.

item.title: 'I thought I could deal with the loss' says Anita Rani
item.description: From presenting Countryfile from her back garden to making food parcels during lockdown, Anita is a doer. But no amount of distraction could ease the pain of her devastating miscarriage

item.title: LOCKDOWN HAIR: Your ultimate survival guide
item.description: With salons still closed, beauty director Edwina Ings-Chambers has all the expert tips you need for DIY colouring, cutting (and, if all else fails, clever accessorising)

item.title: Coronavirus is still spreading uncontrolled in 24 US states, Imperial College London model claims
item.description: The study published on Thursday, which has not been peer reviewed, uses mobility data and case information to estimate the reproduction rate of the virus in each US state.

item.title: First picture of Carrie Symonds's grandad who her and Boris Johnson's baby was named after revealed
item.description: For the first time the public are able to see a picture of Joesph Lawrence, the inspiration for the name of Boris Johnson and Carrie Symonds' son, and find out more about Carrie's maternal grandfather.

item.title: KATE MANSEY: My five-year-old son was in pain with a decaying molar...
item.description: KATE MANSEY: I was flabbergasted. Even if I could pull off this level of dentistry, we're talking about a child in excruciating pain who would surely take it out or perhaps even swallow it.

item.title: PETER HITCHENS: The new authoritarian State's dream has come true
item.description: PETER HITCHENS: We will not be free people again. Even when we seem to be free we will be like prisoners on parole, who can be snatched back to their cells at a moment's notice.

item.title: Are more men dying from coronavirus because of testosterone? Prostate cancer experts believe so
item.description: Testosterone could be the reason why so many men are dying from coronavirus, doctors believe. Twice as many males are succumbing to the disease as women in pattern baffling scientists.

item.title: Top vaccine scientist says coronavirus could only come from an animal through a 'freak of nature'
item.description: Scientists have produced evidence that the pandemic virus is 'uniquely adapted to infect humans', raising fresh questions over whether its origins were natural or could have occurred in a laboratory.

item.title: How greedy landlords are suing students for unpaid rent
item.description: Many university students are being threatened with legal action from letting agents and private landlords unless they pay for accommodation. Jack Clarke, with his father Phil, has lodged a complaint.

item.title: Prince William gives rare insight into parenthood and the impact of Diana's death on his life
item.description: Prince William has spoken in candid detail about how he found himself overwhelmed by parenthood because of the devastating impact of his mother's early death.

item.title: Speculation mounts that 'dark forces' are behind expose on aide who dared to take on Whitehall
item.description: The explosive revelations about Dominic Cummings (pictured) come against the backdrop of growing tensions between the maverick aide and the Whitehall establishment.

item.title: TOM BOWER: Why Boris Johnson will fight to the end for maverick Dominic Cummings
item.description: It is no coincidence that news of Cummings's 'lockdown bust' was broken by two Labour-supporting newspapers, writes TOM BOWER.

item.title: How many alerts have been issued by the NHS track-and-trace app
item.description: Early on Friday morning an orderly queue formed outside the newly-opened Paradice Ice Cream Parlour on the High Street in Cowes.

item.title: AA boss sacked for brawl sues over stress at work
item.description: Bob Mackenzie has accused the AA of failing to support him in the months leading up to his attack on a fellow executive in 2017.

item.title: How to make your own beer for less than 50p a pint
item.description: The closure of pubs, combined with stressed household finances, has caused demand for homebrew kits to soar. But of course, home brewing is not always plain sailing.

item.title: How house buyers are slashing offers and blaming the virus
item.description: The impact of coronavirus is still being felt in the property market - from nervous sellers to buyers trying to scoop a possible bargain. Joe Nutkins (pictured) fears viewers coming to her bungalow.

item.title: Jockey Richard Pitman on money and abolishing income tax
item.description: Former jump jockey Richard Pitman would abolish income tax if he was Chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Engaged couple are furious after wedding insurer uses 'government act loophole' to avoid paying out
item.description: Yasmin Dick and Tyrone Hunt, from London, (pictured) were forced to cancel their wedding due to coronavirus, and were initially told that they were eligible to make an insurance claim.

item.title: Woman admits she was a schoolgirl 'pimp' for paedophile billionaire Jeffrey Epstein
item.description: In a harrowing interview Hayley Robson, now 33, speaks of her involvement in Jeffrey Epstein's web of schoolgirl recruiters when she was 16 years old in Florida.

item.title: US farms are using MORE antibiotics despite warnings that overuse will spread superbugs
item.description: Figures obtained by The Mail on Sunday reveal that the sale of antibiotics to American farms jumped from 5,559 tons in 2017 to 6,036 tons in 2018 - a 9 per cent rise (file photo).

item.title: Farmer feels betrayed after MPs failed to stop food sales in Britain using lower safety standards
item.description: Andrew Ward (pictured), who has 1,600 acres of land in Lincolnshire, said farmers were betrayed after bid to protect Britain from low-standard imports was torpedoed.

item.title: LORD ASHCROFT honours hero of Dunkirk
item.description: Dunkirk was Britain's lowest point of the Second World War. No one showed more grit, determination and courage than Captain Marcus Ervine-Andrews.

item.title: Marks & Spencer's transgender policy 'puts women and girls at risk' from voyeurs, say campaigners
item.description: Campaigners say Marks & Spencer's practice of allowing men who identify as women to use female changing rooms is at odds with the law and could encourage voyeurism.

item.title: Stand up for British farmers against a US invasion of chlorinated chicken
item.description: SIR NICHOLAS SOAMES: We are extraordinarily lucky in this country to be served by some of the most effective and efficient farmers in the world

item.title: How the Woody Allen scandal is ending in a truly startling twist...
item.description: 'Of course I am aware I am the subject of gossip and scandal, but I cannot let it bother me. I live my life. I work. I play jazz. I watch sports. I see my friends. I don't look up and I don't read anything'

item.title: Travel firms to trust for your post-COVID holiday
item.description: Amazing holiday deals are already appearing for 2021, from a self-drive tour through Florida to a safari in Namibia. But which travel firms can be trusted? Neil Simpson investigates.

item.title: Britain's best hotels, B&Bs and perfect pubs with rooms
item.description: The list includes a family-run hotel with mesmerising ocean views in Cornwall and a lodge in Scotland that allows guests to stay in the room where Winston Churchill fine-tuned the D-Day plans.

item.title: Would YOU let a friend trim your lockdown locks? MAUREEN LIPMAN had her hair cut by her trusty PA...
item.description: MAUREEN LIPMAN: I am so happy with my stripey grey hair. Of course, it goes a bit sepia after 49 days of lockdown, and Lord, it could do with a cut. So I asked my trusty PA, Nats, to cut it.

item.title: Ronan Farrow tried to stop a New York magazine profile on Soon-Yi Previn, reporter says
item.description: Journalist Ronan Farrow reportedly tried to stop a 2018 profile about his adopted sister, Soon Yi-Previn, who is Woody Allen's wife, from being published, The New York Post reports.

item.title: Former investment banker becomes YouTube hit after posting videos of him completing SUDOKU puzzles
item.description: Simon Anthony, 46, from Reigate, Surrey, has become a sensation with his YouTube channel Cracking the Cryptic, which has more than 210,000 subscribers worldwide.

item.title: Malaga swimmer comes within inches of huge basking shark off Spain's coast
item.description: A spectacular video shows an unfazed swimmer come within inches of a huge basking shark off the coast of Malaga on Friday. This is the third sighting off Spain's southern waters this month.

item.title: US Navy shows off high-energy LASER WEAPON and shoots down a drone during its first ever at-sea test
item.description: The US Navy shot down a drone with a high-energy laser attached to the USS Portland near Pearl Harbor in Hawaii

item.title: Great-grandmother, 88, becomes TikTok star
item.description: Ruth Rudd has gone viral by doing funny dancing videos outside her house in Kidderminster and scoring a goal in her granddaughter's football which has over 500,000 views.

item.title: Two metre rule could be relaxed raising hopes more pubs and restaurants will be able to reopen
item.description: Professor Yvonne Doyle told MPs that the UK had taken a 'cautionary' approach to introducing the rule when other countries were using shorter distances.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: All arrivals must quarantine for 14 days
item.description: Priti Patel today confirmed all travellers returning to the UK will face a mandatory 14 day period in quarantine as she said Britain must now guard against importing cases of coronavirus.

item.title: Chelsea Flower Show announces amateur gardener winners
item.description: Nearly 8,000 people entered the society's 'My Chelsea Garden' competition. Terry Winters, 62, from Wiltshire, won the prize for Best Back Garden (pictured).
